questions.question: The approach climb requirement has been established to ensure:
options: a. minimum climb gradient in case of a go-around with one engine inoperative
b. obstacle clearance in the approach area
c. manoeuvrability in case of landing with one engine inoperative
d. manoeuvrability during approach with full flaps and gear down, all engines operating
questions.explanation: The approach climb requirement ensures that the aircraft can achieve a minimum climb gradient in case of a go-around with one engine inoperative. This is a critical safety requirement that ensures the aircraft can safely abort a landing and climb away from the runway and surrounding obstacles even with reduced power.

questions.question: The maximum mass for landing could be limited by:
options: a. the climb requirements with all engines in the landing configuration but with gear up
b. the climb requirements with one engine inoperative in the approach configuration
c. the climb requirements with one engine inoperative in the landing configuration
d. the climb requirements with all engines in the approach configuration
questions.explanation: The maximum mass for landing could be limited by the climb requirements with one engine inoperative in the approach configuration. This ensures that if a go-around is necessary during approach, the aircraft can safely climb away with one engine failed.

questions.question: Which of the following is true according to EU-OPS regulations for turbo-propeller powered aeroplanes not performing a steep approach?
options: a. Maximum take-off run is 0.5 x runway length
b. Maximum use of clearway is 1.5 x runway length
c. Maximum landing distance at the destination aerodrome and at any alternate aerodrome is 0.7 x LDA (landing distance available)
d. Maximum landing distance at destination is 0.95 x LDA (landing distance available)
questions.explanation: According to EU-OPS regulations for turbo-propeller powered aeroplanes not performing a steep approach, the maximum landing distance at the destination aerodrome and at any alternate aerodrome is 0.7 x LDA (landing distance available). This provides a safety margin for landing operations.

questions.question: For a turboprop powered aeroplane, a 2200 m long runway at the destination aerodrome is expected to be "wet". To ensure the wet landing distance meets the requirement, the "dry runway" landing distance should not exceed:
questions.explanation: For turboprop aircraft, wet landing distance = dry landing distance × 1.15 (15% increase). Maximum wet landing distance = 0.7 × 2200 m = 1540 m. Therefore, maximum dry landing distance = 1540 m ÷ 1.15 = 1339 m.

questions.question: A flight is planned with a turbojet aeroplane to an aerodrome with a landing distance available of 2400 m. Which of the following is the maximum landing distance for a dry runway?
questions.explanation: For turbojet aircraft, maximum landing distance for dry runway = 0.6 × LDA = 0.6 × 2400 m = 1440 m. The closest answer is 1437 m.

questions.question: According to EU-OPS, which one of the following statements concerning the landing distance for a turbojet aeroplane is correct?
options: a. The landing distance is the distance from 35 ft above the surface of the runway to the full stop
b. When determining the maximum allowable landing mass at destination, 60% of the available landing runway length should be taken into account
c. Reverse thrust is one of the factors always taken into account when determining the landing distance required
d. Malfunctioning of an anti-skid system has no effect on the required runway length
questions.explanation: According to EU-OPS, when determining the maximum allowable landing mass at destination for a turbojet aeroplane, 60% of the available landing runway length should be taken into account. This provides a safety margin for landing operations.

questions.question: By what factor must the landing distance available (dry runway) for a turbojet powered aeroplane be multiplied to find the maximum landing distance?
questions.explanation: For a turbojet powered aeroplane, the landing distance available (dry runway) must be multiplied by 0.60 (60%) to find the maximum landing distance. This ensures adequate safety margins for landing operations.

questions.question: The landing field length required for jet aeroplanes at the alternate in wet conditions is the demonstrated landing distance plus:
questions.explanation: The landing field length required for jet aeroplanes at the alternate in wet conditions is the demonstrated landing distance plus 92%. This accounts for the increased landing distance required on wet runways and provides additional safety margin for alternate airports.

questions.question: The landing field length required for turbojet aeroplanes at the destination in wet condition is the demonstrated landing distance plus:
questions.explanation: The landing field length required for turbojet aeroplanes at the destination in wet condition is the demonstrated landing distance plus 92%. This accounts for the reduced braking effectiveness and increased landing distance on wet runways.

questions.question: For a turbojet aeroplane, what is the maximum landing distance for wet runways when the landing distance available at an aerodrome is 3000 m?
questions.explanation: For turbojet aircraft, maximum landing distance for wet runway = 0.6 × LDA ÷ 1.15 = 0.6 × 3000 m ÷ 1.15 = 1800 m ÷ 1.15 = 1565 m. The closest answer is 1562 m. Alternatively: Maximum dry landing distance = 0.6 × 3000 = 1800 m. Maximum wet landing distance = 1800 ÷ 1.15 = 1565 m ≈ 1562 m.

questions.question: If the airworthiness documents do not specify a correction for landing on a wet runway, the landing distance must be increased by:
questions.explanation: If the airworthiness documents do not specify a correction for landing on a wet runway, the landing distance must be increased by 15%. This accounts for reduced braking effectiveness and increased stopping distance on wet surfaces.

questions.question: Required runway length at destination airport for turboprop aeroplanes:
options: a. is the same as at an alternate airport
b. is less then at an alternate airport
c. is more than at an alternate airport
d. is 60% longer than at an alternate airport
questions.explanation: For turboprop aeroplanes, the required runway length at the destination airport is the same as at an alternate airport. Both require 70% of the landing distance available (LDA).

questions.question: For this question use Figure 4.28 in CAP 698 Section 4. What is the minimum field length required for the worst wind situation, landing a twin jet aeroplane with the anti-skid inoperative? Elevation: 2000 ft QNH: 1013 hPa Landing mass: 50000 kg Flaps: as required for minimum landing distance Runway condition: dry Wind: Maximum allowable tailwind: 15 kt Maximum allowable headwind: 50 kt
questions.explanation: This question requires the use of Figure 4.28 in CAP 698 Section 4. The minimum field length is determined by entering the chart with the given conditions: Elevation 2000 ft, Landing mass 50000 kg, Anti-skid inoperative, and reading the required field length for the worst wind situation (tailwind 15 kt).

questions.question: Compared to the landing distance available, the maximum landing distance for a turbo-propeller and turbojet aircraft are:
questions.explanation: Compared to the landing distance available (LDA), the maximum landing distance for a turbo-propeller aircraft is 70% of LDA, and for a turbojet aircraft is 60% of LDA. This provides safety margins for landing operations.

questions.question: The landing climb gradient limit mass is determined by:
options: a. a gradient of 3.2% with one engine inoperative, the other engines at take-off power in the landing configuration
b. a gradient of 3.2% with all engines operating at take-off power, in the landing configuration
c. a gradient of 2.1% with all engines operating at take-off power, with landing gear retracted, and approach flap
d. a gradient of 3.2% with all engines operating at take-off power, with landing gear retracted and approach flap
questions.explanation: The landing climb gradient limit mass is determined by a gradient of 3.2% with all engines operating at take-off power, in the landing configuration (gear down, flaps in landing position). This ensures the aircraft can safely perform a go-around from a landing approach.
